title-group.article-title: Navigating the Emotional Terrain: Exploring the Psychological Impact of Infertility on Women at a Tertiary Care Hospital

article-meta.aff: Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, AIIMS, Nagpur, Maharashtra, India

abstract.p: Infertility affects one in four couples globally, with significant psycho-social implications. This study explores the psychological footprint of infertility on women’s mental health in a tertiary care hospital, emphasizing the prevalence of distress and the need for targeted interventions to alleviate the emotional burden experienced by infertile women. This cross-sectional study, conducted from April to December 2020, enrolled 132 women with primary infertility (18-45 years) at a tertiary care teaching hospital. Participants completed a questionnaire covering socio-demographic details, reproductive history, social aspects, and the Psychological Evaluation Test (PET). Data analysis included descriptive statistics and inferential analyses using SPSS software, aiming to explore the psychological impact of infertility on women’s lives and identify those in need of psychological support. Out of 132 participants, the mean Psychological Evaluation Test (PET) score was 33.5 ± 5.3, signifying notable psychological distress. Women aged 26-30 constituted the majority (43.2%), with 57.6% residing in rural areas. Primary infertility was prevalent, with a mean duration of 5.9 ± 4.9 years. Most received medical treatment (76%), and 59.8% reported spousal support. Emotional reasons dominated desires for children, while financial problems and infertility treatment were major stressors. The study reveals a high prevalence of psychological distress among infertile women, emphasizing the need for targeted interventions. The study underscores the substantial psychological distress among infertile women, emphasizing the imperative for integrated psychological support. This holistic approach is crucial for enhanced infertility management and improved overall well-being.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Across cultures, procreation is universally acknowledged as a fundamental aspect of adulthood, with religious and societal importance placed on fertility and childbearing. As per the World Health Organization (WHO) estimation, one in every four couples has been affected by infertility.[1] It was considered the fifth most alarming global disability among the reproductive age group population.[2] The overall prevalence of psycho-social issues among infertile couples is estimated to range from 25% to 60%.[34]

Numerous studies underscore the association between infertility and health challenges, encompassing issues such as diminished self-esteem, grief, depression, disappointment, emotional anguish, and marital discord.[567] A hypothesized link between stress–depression dynamics, involving the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis and failure to conceive, suggests that psychological interventions targeting stress may enhance the likelihood of conception.[89]

The brunt of infertility on the mental health of couples has been the topic of concern in recent years. The psychological effect of infertility on women’s lives, personal relations and family is complex and has been well highlighted in literature.[5710] Women have experienced infertility as a devastating failure, resulting in withdrawal from the “fertile world.” Although both spouses are subject to the complications of infertility, appreciating the intensity of consequences that women may suffer, the present study focuses on infertile “women.”

Various questionnaires have been tailored for assessing the psychological aspect of infertility such as the Psychological Evaluation Test (PET), General Health questionnaire-28(GHQ-28), SF-36, fertiQOL (Quality of Life), WHOQOL-BREF (World Health Organization Quality of Life Instrument), and Quality of life index.[11] PET aims to recognize couples requiring psychological support dealing with infertility. It comprises a self-administered questionnaire and provides insight regarding different domains of the psychology of the patient. Researchers have already used PET to evaluate those who are more affected by infertility and may need psychological evaluation and support.[412]

The present study aims to collect information on the psychological effects of infertility on women’s lives and identify women who require psychological support. This information will help in designing a strategy for the management of the psycho-social problems provoked by the situation of infertility. This will assist in decreasing the stress and thereby increasing the chances of conception.

sec.title: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sec.p: A cross-sectional observational study was conducted among women seeking services at the infertility clinic of a tertiary care teaching hospital and its affiliated Urban Health Centre from April 1, 2020, to December 31, 2020. The study focused on women aged 18–45 years with primary infertility, defined as the absence of conception in the subject. Exclusion criteria included a prior history of mental illness. Complete privacy and data anonymity were assured. Institutional Ethics Committee approval (IEC/Pharmac/2020/43) was obtained.

Participants, during face-to-face consultations, responded to a pre-designed, pre-tested screening questionnaire.[412] Each woman received a questionnaire comprising four sections. The first section gathered socio-demographic details, including age, education level, and employment status. The second section covered reproductive history, including the duration of infertility and types of treatments undergone. The third section explored social aspects such as family support and reasons for desiring a child. The fourth section included the PET with 15 questions assessing emotional reactions to infertility-related stressors. Responses were graded based on frequency (1 = never or rarely, 2 = sometimes, 3 = many times, 4 = always), resulting in a PET score ranging from 15 to 60 points. A PET score exceeding 30 points served as the cutoff for requiring specific psychological intervention. Women surpassing this threshold were offered psychological support and management from a certified clinical psychologist.

Data analysis involved entering the collected data into a worksheet, with categorical and continuous data expressed as frequency and mean/median, respectively. Univariate analysis employed the student t-test for continuous variables and the Chi-square test for categorical variables. SPSS software version 22 facilitated data analysis.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Out of 139 infertile women approached for the PET questionnaire, 7 declined participation, resulting in the inclusion of 132 women in the study. The mean age of participants was 28.7 ± 4.9 years, with the highest proportion (43.2%) falling in the 26–30 age group. Educational attainment indicated that 47.7% had completed higher secondary education, and the majority (71.2%) identified as homemakers. Around 18.9% of the study population were skilled workers. Collecting data on skilled and unskilled occupations is crucial for understanding how income, job stability, workplace support, and social dynamics intersect with infertility stressors. Disparities in financial resources, healthcare access, and workplace flexibility can significantly impact the experience of infertility-related distress among women from diverse occupational backgrounds. Residency distribution revealed that 57.6% lived in rural areas, and 56.1% resided in joint families. The mean age at marriage was 22.4 ± 3.4 years and the mean duration of marriage was 6.4 years.

Skilled workers might have access to social networks with greater awareness and acceptance of infertility struggles, whereas unskilled workers may encounter more stigma or lack of understanding regarding their fertility challenges, which can contribute to feelings of isolation and distress. Table 1 provides detailed baseline characteristics.

tr.td: Illiterate Primary Middle Secondary Higher Secondary Graduate and above
Illiterate Primary Middle Secondary Higher Secondary Graduate and above
Unskilled worker Semiskilled worker Skilled worker Self employed

sec.p: All participants in the study experienced primary infertility, with a mean duration of infertility lasting 5.9 ± 4.9 years. Of these, 76 women had undergone medical treatment, including ovulation induction drugs, with a mean treatment duration of 4.1 ± 2.9 years. Although 59.8% received spousal support during treatment, 53% reported a lack of support from relatives.

For the majority (86.6%) of participants, the primary reason for desiring a child was to experience pregnancy and childbirth, with three-fourths expressing a desire for companionship in old age. Motherhood, financial challenges, and infertility treatment emerged as major stressors leading to psychological disorders, as depicted in Figure 1. Examining attitudes, 48% of participants were hopeful for conception in the near future, as illustrated in Figure 2. The inferential analysis, including the statistical correlation of study variables with PET scores, is presented in Table 2.

caption.p: Various predisposing stress factors causing psychological disorders
Alternative plans of study participants on remaining childless

Duration of treatment taken for infertility (in years)

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The current study delves into the psychological distress experienced by infertile women, employing PET as a diagnostic tool. This has been demonstrated in Figure 3. The mean PET score of 33.5 ± 5.3 indicates a considerable level of psychological distress, surpassing scores reported in previous studies by Sujindra et al.[4] (28.3 ± 8.4) and Franco et al.[12] The elevated distress levels, with 81% of women exceeding the cutoff of 30, spotlight the pressing need for psychological interventions in this demographic. The findings resonate with global studies, emphasizing the universality of the emotional consequences of infertility. Comparable studies by Hasanpoor-Azghdy et al.[3] in Iran and Hess et al.[7] in Mali also highlight the profound psychological impact of infertility on women. The increasing prevalence of stress, particularly in this region, underscores the necessity of integrating psychological counseling into the holistic care of infertile women.

caption.p: The PET questionnaire and the responses of infertile women

sec.p: The stigma associated with infertility is evident in the study, with 77.2% of women reporting feelings of emptiness and 43.2% expressing an inferiority complex, contributing to low self-esteem. This aligns with the work of Sujindra et al.,[4] emphasizing the far-reaching effects on identity and interpersonal relationships. Similar findings were also reported in other studies where the women felt that their identity was lost and this feeling had undermined their relationship with others.[713] Furthermore, the emotional burden is compounded by the disappointment associated with menstrual cycles, affecting 92.4% of women in this study, echoing the findings of Sujindra et al.[4] regarding the impact of menstruation on emotional well-being. The exacerbation of anxiety due to the mere absence of children in their lives has been shown to produce somatic reactions in infertile couples.[12] The current study reported similar findings wherein 36.4% of the infertile women had autonomic symptoms due to thoughts about their childlessness.

The study highlights the significance of psycho-social support, as evidenced by the positive correlation between perceived spousal support and overall well-being. The majority of women acknowledged spousal support, reinforcing the importance of a strong support system in coping with the challenges of infertility.[814]

Many studies suggested that in societies, where, having children is an important obligation and a necessary outcome of marriage, infertility is more liable to have a deleterious impact on the couples’ relationship.[4141516] In the present study, approximately 3.7% of women reported having marital problems due to infertility and 2.27% stated their sexual life was affected due to not having a child. Limited adoption options in India, coupled with societal attitudes, contribute to the reluctance (9.1%) of women to consider adoption. These findings resonate with global discussions on the socio-cultural implications of infertility and the unique challenges faced by infertile couples.

Additionally, it has also been observed that women belonging to the age group 26–35 years, experienced higher levels of anxiety.[1417] Due to a variety of reasons, a marriage is being delayed, and consequently so is the first pregnancy. Thus, women have to increasingly resort to adopting options such as donors, surrogacy, adoption or opt to remain childless. However, regardless of age, infertility and the treatments available have a deep impact on psychology. The adverse effect of infertility with women having higher educational levels reporting higher rates of infertility was elicited in a study by Dovom et al.[18] as well as that by Skirbekk.[19] In contrast, Katole et al[17] depicted that education has a preventive effect on depression. Studies by Katole et al[17] and Yusoff et al.[20] found that employed women are less predisposed to depression. This was in contradiction to the data in NFHS-3 (National Family Health Survey), which notified that working women are more likely to be infertile compared to non-working women (20%).[21]

Although demographic variables such as age, age of marriage, education, and occupation did not show significant correlations with PET scores, the duration of infertility and the treatment undertaken emerged as influential factors. Longer duration of infertility was associated with increased frustration, aligning with existing literature on the cumulative psychological toll over time.[22232425]

The study calls for an integrated approach to infertility management, emphasizing the imperative role of psychological support alongside medical interventions. Incorporating counseling sessions into routine care, as advocated by the Mind/Body program, could offer a promising avenue for addressing the emotional well-being of infertile couples. The study opens avenues for further research on the long-term impact of psychological interventions on conception rates and the overall quality of life for infertile women.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: Strengths of this study include a comprehensive assessment using the PET, a substantial sample size with diverse demographics, and ethical considerations. However, limitations include the cross-sectional design that impedes causal inference, a single-center setting limits generalizability, self-reporting introduces bias, exclusion of previous mental illness limits applicability, and the lack of comparison groups hinders insights into unique psychological challenges faced by infertile women compared to their fertile counterparts.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: In conclusion, this study sheds light on the significant psychological distress experienced by infertile women, as evidenced by elevated PET scores. The findings underscore the need for integrated psychological support in infertility care. Addressing emotional well-being alongside medical interventions is crucial to enhance the holistic management of infertility and improve the overall quality of life for affected women. Further research should explore the long-term impacts of psychological interventions on conception rates and the overall well-being of infertile couples.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: The study was approved by the institutional ethics committee.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: There are no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The authors would like to thank all patients who took part in this study and also thank the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology for their support and cooperation.
